text: The point is to make a highly liquid coin more private and fungible, and not the other way around.
name: SatoshiLite

text: It‚Äôs not TPS that is the issue. I‚Äôm not convinced Monero can overcome the indefinite TXO growth at scale. When TXO gets too large, it becomes hard to run a node. Maybe I‚Äôm wrong and it‚Äôs not an issue. Actually, I hope I‚Äôm wrong, but that doesn‚Äôt stop me from working on Litecoin.
name: SatoshiLite

text: Tari‚Äôs solution is a MW sidechain, which is very similar to our MWEB solution on Litecoin. Like I said, the problem is liquidity of the coin. You can have a perfect privacy coin but without liquidity, it‚Äôs useless. So my approach is to make an already liquid coin more private.
name: SatoshiLite

text: Monero will have scaling issues if it becomes popular due to TXO size growing indefinitely. Also, Monero is not on a lot of exchanges and is not very liquid. It‚Äôs good to strive for more privacy and fungibility on Litecoin and Bitcoin, no?

text: Or maybe, I killed the real creator of Litecoin, stole his identity and his private keys. And I‚Äôm now pretending to be the creator and no one will ever find out. I can never ever prove that‚Äôs not what happened. Because any information I have, one can claim I stole it.

text:
The proof is not and will never eliminate an infinite world of possibilities.

For example, someone else created Litecoin and I am just a front man to hide that fact. So he signed a message saying I created it. There‚Äôs no proof in the world that can disprove this possibility.
name: SatoshiLite

text:
1) I claim that I created Litecoin
2) Create of Litecoin presumably owns the genesis private key
3) Owner of genesis private key signed the message that he is Charlie Lee and he created Litecoin

How much more proof do you need? This is the best proof you can practically do.
name: SatoshiLite

text:
Yes, I signed with my private key to the genesis address. That‚Äôs the best way to prove ownership of a private key in the crypto space.

You can verify my message, by putting the message (without quotes), signature, & address in the Litecoin client or here:
name: SatoshiLite

text: This mining cartel currently owns only ~28% of the BCH hashrate. They can't enforce this coercive soft fork unless they come up with a lot more hashrate. And it would likely lead to many forks. Adding such a centralizing feature in this coercive manner sets such a bad precedent.

CJ on MW is a lot simpler and easier to use than it is on BTC/LTC.

1) MW has CT, so all amounts are hidden and there‚Äôs no need to decide on a uniform output size.

2) With aggregation in MW, there‚Äôs no need to sign the final CJ transaction. So one can't DoS by not to signing.

text: Miners are people also. UASF won‚Äôt work if miners shoot themselves in the foot to attack the user‚Äôs chain. That‚Äôs not good for anyone. It‚Äôs not black and white. I don‚Äôt have time to explain this, but it‚Äôs not as simple as you make it out to be.
name: SatoshiLite

text: How much work and how long did you think it took us to convince them to start signaling in the first place. Some FUD or arm twisting by Jihan caused them to stop signaling. All you saw was the end result.
name: SatoshiLite

text: Unlike trolling, which you can easily do in seconds.
name: SatoshiLite

text: Correct. We will try to implement this as modular as possible. So we can get easily merge in Bitcoin improvements and also MimbleWimble improvements.
name: SatoshiLite

text: It was hard work to convince people that they had the power over miners via UASF. It was also a lot of work to convince the miners to signal for SegWit. Maybe it looked easy from where you were sitting. I spent probably hundreds of hours chatting and talking to miners about it.
name: SatoshiLite

text:
Miners only feared UASF after it was proven to them that the market valued SegWit on Litecoin by the price movement strongly correlated with signaling threshold.

And this was only possible after a lot of convincing to get f2pool and another large miner to signal for SegWit.
name: SatoshiLite

text: You can‚Äôt sybil signal with mining hashrate. And miners don‚Äôt have to reveal their IPs.
name: SatoshiLite

text: It wasn‚Äôt easy at all. It took months. You weren‚Äôt paying attention and have no idea what you are talking about.
name: SatoshiLite

text: Node numbers were never important. It‚Äôs hard to signal and calculate concensus. Just ask Satoshi. He had to invent Bitcoin to do it. :D
name: SatoshiLite

text: You don‚Äôt need to know which nodes receive coins, but those nodes matter also.
name: SatoshiLite

text: If there‚Äôs apathy, then the softfork won‚Äôt be as safe. So for example, if only 20% of the economic nodes upgrade, then miners can rollback the softfork knowing that 80% of the network will follow the rollback. This would lead to a coin fork, which is bad.
name: SatoshiLite

text:
Don‚Äôt get me wrong. This is without expectation of anything w.r.t. Bitcoin. It‚Äôs a low probability Bitcoin will do EB/MW in my opinion. But it‚Äôs 0 chance unless it‚Äôs shown to work on Litecoin.

Nodes that spend and receive coins are economic nodes. So exchanges and user nodes.
name: SatoshiLite

text: Yo     how do I get one of these in Wisconsin????
name: SatoshiLite

text: For activation, only majority of miners need to support. But over time as the majority of nodes support it, it will really lock in. That‚Äôs why we propose to use BIP8 to lock in after 1 year assuming it‚Äôs enough time for maority of economic nodes to support it.

text: Mining is how Bitcoin and Litecoin is distributed fairly. Miners being greedy is in the whitepaper. Bitcoin works if miners are greedy. Bitcoin doesn‚Äôt care if miners are in it for profit or in it for ideology.
name: SatoshiLite

text: No need to attack me personally. I never thought printing money out of thin air is a good idea. Unless you think I printed Litecoin out of thin air. You must not understand how mining works.
name: SatoshiLite

text: I disagree pretty strongly with this. Bitcoin was too powerful of an idea to not have succeeded even if everyone was in it for profit from the start. The whole point of Bitcoin working is that people act selfishly and for profit and Bitcoin still works.
name: SatoshiLite

text: But we are still in the middle of distribution. Half the coins are distributed after the first halving (4 years). I don‚Äôt see why the initial 1 year of coins (1/8 of all coins) matters more for incentives to make Bitcoin not a scam and other coins a scam.

text: What does volume have to do with number of coins. But you do bring up another source of issue. If an exchange is running a fraction reserve, how does that not dilute your coins in your definition of coin dilution? Unless everyone withdraws from all exchanges onchain.

text: There will be fees and spread with atomic swaps, so you won't get 1:1 conversion.

text: Not everyone is out of Liquid or LN. How are you sure your onchain coins are not diluted? I assume you don't understand everything about Liquid or LN and don't know 100% there's no hidden inflation in either of those networks.
name: SatoshiLite

text:
This is a good thought experiment.

Pegouts take a while to be spendable. So if you want to cash out your MW coins immediately, you may be willing to get less for it.

Also, miners can potentially block pegouts by censoring them. That could create a price discrepancy.
name: SatoshiLite

text:
Same risk as paper gold diluting value of real gold. When government's start printing fiat and it was no longer backed by real gold, did that dilute the value of gold?

Not exactly the same I admit, but a decent analogy to think through.
name: SatoshiLite

text: Maxwell created Crypto Twitter? Amazing!
name: SatoshiLite

text: Indiana Jones comes to mind. üòÉ
name: SatoshiLite

text: Or you can go into EB but not out. üòÆ
name: SatoshiLite

text: Would be interesting to see how this plays out. We're designing it such that 1 LTC is 1 LTC no matter where.
name: SatoshiLite

text: In this case, a run in the bank would be people rushing to peg-out. There's a risk for people using MW, but not on the canonical side. If you choose to opt-in to using MW, you should be willing to accept that risk.
name: SatoshiLite

text: By definition, a softfork forces all miners to follow the rules or they are orphaned. So after the fork, no miners can create a block that‚Äôs invalid. (i.e. spending incorrectly from anyone-can-spend) So no, you can‚Äôt force a split.
name: SatoshiLite

text:
Softfork means if you don‚Äôt update your node, you will still be able to validate what you know and would not consider the blockchain invalid after the softfork.

So after the softfork, all miners are required to validate everything. Even if no users update, it won‚Äôt hardfork.
name: SatoshiLite

text: EB comes with a compromise. Of course! So did SegWit. The question is if the compromise is worth the benefit we are getting. No one is saying EB is flawless.
name: SatoshiLite

text:
Coins don‚Äôt appear out of nowhere. For this proposal, old nodes will see coins sit in the HogAddr, which holds all the coins in the EB corresponding to that block.

Just like with SegWit, old nodes will see those "anyone-can-spend‚Äù spent to a normal address. That‚Äôs the peg-out.
name: SatoshiLite

text: That doesn‚Äôt make much sense. How does EB give miners power to force a fork?
name: SatoshiLite

text:
3 things:
- atomic swaps require agreeing to a market price
- there‚Äôs going to be a spread, so you lose value
- there may not be liquidity

With EB, you can always move your LTC across the 2 without losing money. 1 LTC on canonical chain = 1 LTC on extension chain.
name: SatoshiLite

text: What you said applies to every single softfork including SegWit. Miners are required to validate all the new consensus rules. No one is downplaying anything. If you have a valid criticism that differentiates EB from other softforks, we haven‚Äôt heard it yet. Explain again maybe.
name: SatoshiLite

text:
That's true for any soft fork. New nodes have to validate everything. Old nodes don't need to.

One nice thing about EB is that you isolate potential flaws like inflation bugs to the EB, and won't affect the canonical chain. If you move coins there, you are accepting that risk

This is why I don‚Äôt want a vested financial interest. Money can cloud things.

For companies, share price == company success. CEOs are paid to increase shareholder value. That‚Äôs their job.

For crypto, success is not exactly price. I‚Äôm not paid to increase price. So I can focus on long term success and not worry about price.

text: Nothing specifically to do with electricity. The difference is that hashrate requires both a capital cost and an ongoing expense. So a failed attack is costly. Basically the nothing at stake criticism of proof of stake that makes centralization more of an issue.
name: SatoshiLite

text: The key difference is that miners have to spend electricity to mine. So it's not free. Whereas with PoS like in Dash, wealthy can sit around and earn interest and also make decisions for the network.
name: SatoshiLite

text: That's a very centralizing feature.
name: SatoshiLite

text:
Dash masternode system is proof of stake though, right? You need proof of 1000(?) coins to be a masternode.

Dash doesn't create PoS blocks, but I think ChainLocks is actually less secure than Peercoin PoS/PoW blocks because 60% stake (or less) can control everything in Dash.
name: SatoshiLite

text: Indeed, but it's similar to Peercoin where you are effectively relying on both proof of work and proof of stake to make attacks harder.
name: SatoshiLite

text:
I‚Äôm not arguing that it is. That‚Äôs a whole another topic. The point is there‚Äôs still a 51% attack (well 60% in this case) on just a different resource: coins and not hashrate.

Is it harder? Maybe
Is it better? Maybe

I personally prefer hashrate over letting the wealthy decide.
name: SatoshiLite

‚Äúone cannot fix the 51% attack flaw‚Äù

‚Äúone cannot fix the 51% attack flaw‚Äù

name: SatoshiLite

text:
Nowhere does Greg mention anything about what nodes know.

Dash‚Äôs ChainLocks just moves the 51% attack surface from mining to masternodes. If you controls >60% of masternodes, you don‚Äôt need mining as you can dictate which blocks are valid.

Please correct me if I‚Äôm wrong.
name: SatoshiLite

text: One of the benefits of having a coin like Litecoin and other cryptocurrencies is that one can‚Äôt take down every coin. So even if you manage to take down Bitcoin, another coin will rise up. This makes it not worth it to spend the money to take down Bitcoin.
name: SatoshiLite

text: There's not enough machines for you to rent. You have to consider the capital costs of acquiring those machines.
name: SatoshiLite

text:
Read Greg Maxwell's explanation about why one cannot fix the 51% attack flaw of a decentralized system without adding centralization.

This is one of the keys to understanding Bitcoin, proof of work, and decentralization. Most people fail to grasp this.

text: 10/ This is how Litecoin Core development has functioned for years. We even had the same FUD last year! Someone looked at our master branch last year and claimed that Litecoin stopped developing in 2018. And I bet even after this explanation, we will have people confused in 2020.
name: SatoshiLite

text:
9/ The reality is that Adrian has been actively working on Litecoin Core release 0.18.1 on his personal branch here: 

When we release 0.18.1, Adrian will merge his branch into master. When that happens, it would all of a sudden add all the 2019 commits. üò≤
name: SatoshiLite

text: 8/ Second reason is we don't work on the master branch of the main project. It's generally not good dev practice to check in non-release code into the master branch. This is because if someone builds from source from master branch, they might get a broken build and that's bad.
name: SatoshiLite

text: 7/ What this means in practice is that although we did work on and release the latest Litecoin Core in May of 2019, if you look at GitHub, most of the commits where done in 2018. So it would seem like Litecoin developers took the year off.
name: SatoshiLite

text: 6/ But the code that was released was mostly written in 2018. The interesting thing about GitHub is that it keeps the commit the same in terms of who wrote it and when it was committed to the code base. So Bitcoin developers are credited for their work in the Litecoin code base.
name: SatoshiLite

text:
5/ First reason is Litecoin releases lag Bitcoin releases by a few months. So when we do a release, we are releasing code that's been released in Bitcoin months ago.

We actually did release Litecoin Core 0.17.1 May of this year:

text: 4/ Recently there's been a lot of FUD about Litecoin having no code commits in 2019. When you look at Litecoin GitHub (), it would seem like we did no work in 2019. There are actually 2 reasons why this is the case even though we have been developing.
name: SatoshiLite

text: 3/ Adrian Gallagher (AKA thrasher) is leading Litecoin Core development right now and has been for a few years now. You may not know Adrian well as he is not on Twitter much, but he is awesome. He quietly has been working hard behind the scenes on Litecoin Core development. üëç
name: SatoshiLite

text: 2/ It's no secret that we have purposefully kept Litecoin's code very close to Bitcoin's code. Since we are mostly just merging in Bitcoin changes, we only need a lead Litecoin Core developer doing the merges and the rest of us help with code reviews, testing, and gitian builds.

text: I just lost some brain cells reading that. Sorry, but I don't have time to explain it to you over and over again.
name: SatoshiLite

text:
Refer back to the million sided dice. Make that 2^256 sided dice if you will. Collision is extremely rare so if you roll a 2, is the possible outputs less now because rolling a 2 again is extremely low probability?

Math is the same. Mining and dice rolls have no memory.
name: SatoshiLite

text: Yeah, if the number of outputs is finite, it can collide. Chances are extremely small, but it's possible.
name: SatoshiLite

text: Hashes are not unique and can collide and miners don't know what hashes have previously been seen by other miners. So no, it does nothing to deduct from the pool of possible outputs.
name: SatoshiLite

text: That's like saying you have to account for all the non-1s you've previously rolled, which means the odds of rolling a 1 is greater.
name: SatoshiLite

text: No, because you also sometimes find blocks sooner than 10 mins. So it averages to 10 mins.
name: SatoshiLite

text: Doing release candidate builds right now. Will have the RC out soon.
name: SatoshiLite

text: No, that's exactly it. Hashing is like flipping a coin, except it's like a million sided dice and you have to roll a 1. It's 1 in a million chance. If you've previously unable to roll a 1 in 500,000 rolls, what are the chances you will roll a 1 next? It's still 1 in a million.
name: SatoshiLite

text: The extension blocks concept is similar to sidechains. Think of this as a MimbleWimble sidechain that is attached to the main chain using consensus via a softfork upgrade. You can opt-in by sending coins into the MW extension blocks and also send coins out back to the main chain.

text: 5/5 If this is not true, then it's not decentralized as you have to trust someone to tell you which is the right chain. The whole point of decentralization and sound money is that you don't have to trust anyone.
name: SatoshiLite

text: 4/ If you spin up a new node with the same consensus rules as the network, you need to come to the same conclusion as the rest of the network as to which is the right chain. The whole decentralized consensus is pretty much based on this simple fact to be true.
name: SatoshiLite

text: 3/ I have also considered preventing large re-orgs in the code but decided against it. There is a very good reason why I didn't do this in Litecoin and why Satoshi didn't do it for Bitcoin. Satoshi said it best in one of his emails.
name: SatoshiLite

text: 2/ It's trading off some centralization for network stability and reliability. Satoshi also used checkpoints in Bitcoin in the beginning. Though one can say that it is similar to the idea of UASF as users can decide whether or not to run or upgrade to the latest checkpoints.
name: SatoshiLite

text: 1/ In the early days of Litecoin (2011), there were threats of 51% attacks. To keep Litecoin secure, I utilized checkpoints. Checkpointing is a centralizing feature as it relies on the developers deciding which is the right chain. But for the beginning of a coin, it made sense.

text: PS. Early Bitcoin clients had a send to IP feature (in addition to send to address) that lets you make p2p payments. This was removed in subsequent clients. LN actually brings back p2p payments to Bitcoin, while making it more scalable, more flexible, more private, and cheaper!

text: 6/6 Bitcoin with Lightning Network more closely fits the Bitcoin whitepaper's title: "A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Cash System." This is Satoshi's Vision.
name: SatoshiLite

text: 5/ Because LN payments are peer-to-peer, they can work if the peers involved are disconnected from the rest of the internet. The sender can even send payments directly to the recipient by just having a direct connection without relying on any other parties at all.
name: SatoshiLite

text: 4/ Lightning network payments, on the other hand, are p2p payments. They are sometimes direct p2p, sometimes indirect p2p. LN payments have to be sent from peer to peer to get from the sender to the recipient. Both have to be online, just like other p2p networks like BitTorrent.
name: SatoshiLite

text: 3/ This is actually a good thing as the recipient doesn't have to be online to receive payments. Ironically, on chain payments resembles more closely to a hub and spoke model where the mining pools are the hubs and users just need to connect to those hubs to send payments.
name: SatoshiLite

text: 2/ The broadcast network IS p2p, but strictly speaking payments are not p2p. The sender can ignore the p2p network and directly communicate the transaction to miners to send payments. The sender doesn't have to have any communication with the recipient in any p2p manner at all!
name: SatoshiLite

text: 1/ On-chain Bitcoin and Litecoin payments are not peer-to-peer. Payments are sent from sender to miners, who record it on a distributed ledger. The recipient receives the payment when it's recorded. BUT, this is facilitated by a p2p network where transactions are broadcasted.
name: SatoshiLite

text: This happened due to a spam attack in 2011/2012. We've considered actually just marking all these UTXOs as unspendable and delete them from the UTXO set. This is not a huge problem and could easily be solved by a simple soft fork. We just haven't bothered with it.

text:
Exchanges and merchant processors have likely all upgraded to protect themselves. There are no incentives for miners to cheat. Nakamoto consensus game theory is working as designed.

If we have to resort to publicly shaming people to upgrade their nodes, we have already failed.
name: SatoshiLite

text: If anything, getting everyone upgraded immediately to 0.16.3 is a lot more dangerous for a decentralized network. Having client diversity is very important as there may be new bugs in newer versions. People should take their time to get comfortable with upgrades.
name: SatoshiLite

text: There is no urgency to have all nodes upgraded to 0.16.3. The majority of hashrate has already upgraded, so they will ensure an invalid block is orphaned. This is no different than 0.13 nodes not upgrading and trusting miners to enforce SegWit outputs aren't spent incorrectly.
name: SatoshiLite

text: Another maybe better option with better backwards compatibility is to just piggy back off the Bitcoin URI and add another parameter "ln=", which should be ignored by non-LN-aware wallets.
name: SatoshiLite

text:
Right now, when merchants accepts both BTC (or LTC) and LN payments, they let the user choose which option, which is bad UX. Ideally, the user shouldn't have to know and the wallet figures it out for them.

To keep things backwards compatible, how about a QRcode within a QRcode?
name: SatoshiLite

text:
11/ FUD: Charlie has quit Litecoin and doesn't care anymore.

TRUTH: I'm working on Litecoin full-time and focused on Litecoin adoption. Proof: the fact that I spent time writing these 11 tweets! üòÄ

Litecoin also has the strongest crypto community. #LitecoinFam üöÄ
name: SatoshiLite

text:
10/ FUD: Litecoin has no development in the past 6 months.

TRUTH: We don't work on the master branch, where people are looking. This is generally good Git practice! Proof: we released 0.16.2 last week and just released 0.16.3 today, which fixed the recent critical DoS bug.
name: SatoshiLite

text: 9/ Litecoin helped Bitcoin activate SegWit last year by proving the game theory of SegWit in practice. Bitcoin's own testnet3 can't do it because testnet3 coins have no value, so no incentives for malicious actors to hack it. Litecoin helps Bitcoin. That is extremely valuable.
name: SatoshiLite

text:
8/ FUD: Litecoin as Bitcoin's testnet is not worth $3B.

TRUTH: Even if Litecoin's only use case is a testnet, you can't put an absolute value on it. Need to look at it relative to Bitcoin. Litecoin's marketcap is only 3% of Bitcoin's marketcap. That is not very large at all!
name: SatoshiLite

text:
7/ Litecoin will always be the cheapest and fastest on ramp to Lightning Network. And with solutions like submarine swaps, you can use on chain LTC to pay for a BTC lightning invoice!

We will also have decentralized exchanges using atomic swaps. The possibilities are endless. ‚ö°
name: SatoshiLite

text:
6/ FUD: Litecoin is no longer needed now that Bitcoin can scale with LN.

TRUTH: Many of the LN clients and apps also support LTC because they see the value of Litecoin. With atomic swaps, LTC interoperates with BTC on the Lightning Network.
name: SatoshiLite

text:
5/ Litecoin processes $200MM worth of transactions each day. And the network has worked flawlessly for 7 years!

Litecoin works today as a global decentralized sound money, that can't be censored, can't be reversed or taken away, can't be counterfeited, and can't be devalued. üöÄ
name: SatoshiLite

text: 4/ Litecoin is supported by 9+ payment processors: Aliant Payment, BTCPay, Coinbase, CoinGate, CoinPayments, Globee, GoCoin LTCPay, and TravelbyBit. This makes it extremely easy for merchants to accept LTC. There are too many LTC merchants to count! #PayWithLitecoin
name: SatoshiLite

text:
3/ Miners have no incentives to attack the network because it will destroy the value of their ASIC hardware.

Litecoin has a ton of liquidity, which is important for people to get in/out of LTC. It is on practically every fiat and crypto exchange (Gemini soon), even more than ETH
name: SatoshiLite

text:
2/ FUD: Litecoin has lost its edge and can't differentiate itself from hundreds of other altcoins.

TRUTH: Litecoin has one of the most secure networks of all altcoins. Litecoin has over $150MM of ASIC hardware protecting it. Litecoin dominates Scrypt mining by far.
name: SatoshiLite

text: 1/ Recently, there has been a concerted effort to suppress Litecoin price by people/funds that are shorting LTC and by groups that see Litecoin as a threat. I will clear up this FUD and show why Litecoin has tremendous value.
name: SatoshiLite

Time is money. I'm now working full-time on Litecoin and more invested in its success than ever. üöÄ
name: SatoshiLite

text: 4/ Finally, a bit about hodling. The term came from a bitcointalk forum user who refused to sell when the market is crashing. To hodl means to not panic sell when prices are down. Selling during a bull market does not contradict the advice of hodling.
name: SatoshiLite

text: 3/ re: conflict of interest, I sold my LTC holdings so I could focus on adoption and not price, as those 2 are not always correlated. Litecoin is my baby, so I don't need monetary incentive to want it to succeed.
name: SatoshiLite

text: 2/ I said half-jokingly that it's good that I did what I did or else I might need to find another job and can't work full-time on Litecoin (not to mention help fund the Litecoin Foundation). Of course, that's the only point this journalist picked up on and took no time to bash me
name: SatoshiLite

text: 1/ At the LTC Summit, I briefly addressed the motivation behind selling my LTC holdings. However, bad journalism is rampant in crypto, and now there's a sensational headline created out of a partial quote from me.
name: SatoshiLite

text: That's pretty dumb. The market cap today is $3B. I've said many times that I had to mine and buy the LTC I owned just like anyone else. Didn't do an ICO or a crowd sale or anything like that. When I sold it was less than 1% of gdax volume. Didn't move the price at all. All FUD.
name: SatoshiLite

text:
Hodl was coined by a person on bitcointalk that refused to sell when the market was crashing. He would hodl through it. I took that to mean don't sell when the market is crashing because it will recover.

No where is hodl defined as never sell no matter what.
